entry.title: How to use Axios with React
entry.summary:
Introduction
Axios is a promise-based HTTP Client for node.js and the browser. Thus, it works equally well in front-end JavaScript applications and back-end Node servers. This article shows how to use Axios in a simple React application. React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, so we'll use Axios here for browser-based user interfaces. To follow along, you‚Äôll need the following: version 16.16.0 installed on your computer.
A new React project set up with Create React App
IDE or text editor of your choice, such as Sublime Text or Visual Studio Code
We will cover: Sending CRUD API requests with Axios
How to make a GET request How to make a PUT request
How to make a DELETE request
Handling errors
Base Instance

entry.title: Temporal API - A new approach to managing Date and Time in JS
entry.summary:
Introduction
Date object is the least-fun thing and a long-standing pain point in JavaScript. That's why there're other libraries like moment.js and date-fns. Developers use these to make sense of Date object. Implementation of Date object was directly copied from Java. Java scrapped it, but it remained in JavaScript for backward compatibility. It was written a long-time ago and not updated. There're some basic issues with the current Date implementation. Supports only UTC and user's local time zone The Date object is mutable: a date will change as methods are applied Parsing dates from strings is unreliable No support for non-Gregorian calendars Computation APIs are clunky Steps we‚Äôll cover: What Is The Temporal API? Project setup Temporal.Now Temporal.PlainDate Temporal.Duration Tempor‚Ä¶

entry.title: Transcription service Otter is making free users pay to access older recordings
entry.summary:
Image: Otter.ai
Automated transcription service Otter is making some big changes to its offerings for both free and paying customers. Mostly, the company is downgrading its features ‚Äî reducing the number of audio imports users can make; the length of audio they can transcribe each month, and so on ‚Äî though it is giving free users access to some new tools. One of the biggest changes, though, is that free users will no longer be able to access their full back catalogue of recordings. Instead, they‚Äôll only have access to the most recent 25. The rest will be ‚Äúarchived‚Äù ‚Äî that is, they‚Äôll still exist on Otter‚Äôs servers, but users will have to either delete other conversations to access them, or pay to upgrade to Otter‚Äôs ‚Äúpro‚Äù plan. This and other changes to... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to set up SFTP server on Ubuntu(AWS-EC2)
entry.summary:
‚ñ†Introduction About the SFTP SFTP stands for SSH File Transfer Protocol. As its name suggests, it‚Äôs a secure way to transfer files between machines using an encrypted SSH connection. Despite the name, it‚Äôs a completely different protocol than FTP (File Transfer Protocol), though it‚Äôs widely supported by modern FTP clients.
In some cases, you might want only certain users to be allowed file transfers and no SSH access. In this tutorial, we‚Äôll set up the SSH daemon to limit SFTP access to one directory with no SSH access allowed on a per-user basis. So, let‚Äôs start the SFTP setup. Step 1ÔºöInstall OpenSSH-server & SSH $ sudo apt install openssh-server
You also need SSH on the system from where you are going to access the SFTP server. $ sudo apt install ssh
Step 2ÔºöCreate SFTP user account $ ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Monokle 1.10 improves on cluster inspection
entry.summary: We're happy to announce Monokle 1.10 - now adding a bunch of interactive features to help you inspect your k8s clusters: Open a shell directly to a pod from the UI Follow pod logs in the UI Scale / Restart actions See object age/status directly in the k8s navigator We've also added a terminal to help you run your fav cli tools from inside the UI - and improved the integrated OPA validations, global search-and-replace, Docker Image inspector, Cluster-compare, etc. etc. Lot's of goodies to make your everyday GitOps / Kubernetes configuration workflows so much easier! As before - Monokle is 100% OSS/MIT licensed and free to download from GitHub - no registration required. If you have any feedback - good or bad - we'd love to hear it! Download the latest release from GitHub: https://github.com/kubeshop/monokle Release announcement is at https://kubeshop.io/blog/monokle-v1-10-release-notes Oh - and it's Monokles' 1 year anniversary - Happy Birthday!

entry.title: My journey with Kubernetes
entry.summary:
My journey with Kubernetes Mike Dame Fri, 08/19/2022 - 03:00
Register or Login to like Register or Login to like Recently, I published my first book, The Kubernetes Operator Framework Book from Packt Publishing. Writing a book has always been a personal goal of mine, and so it seems fitting that I was able to check that off by writing about one of my favorite topics: Kubernetes. My journey with Kubernetes began in 2016, as a software engineer for Red Hat OpenShift. There, I had the opportunity to work with (and learn from) some of the smartest folks in the open source community. I learned first-hand some of the best practices for Kubernetes development as they were applied to broad enterprise use cases. And as I watched the development of OpenShift 4 take shape, I got to witness the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: App Screenshot Generator ‚Äî A 100% free tool for creating app store screenshots
entry.summary:
https://progressier.com), I've made our app screenshot designer tool a standalone product available to anyone who needs it, free of charge.
There are many alternatives for creating screenshots for the app stores. However, I thought it would be cool to make one that: - anyone can use without signing up - has mockups of recent phones - works on mobile - doesn't lock features behind paywalls - renders screenshots without watermarks - is completely free
It's optimized specifically for creating PWA screenshots (you can enter a URL and it'll screenshot it for you). But you could also use it for generating screenshots for the App Store, Google Play, or even Product Hunt.
If you have any questions, please let me know! ‚Äù

entry.title: I am once again asking you to update your Apple devices
entry.summary:
Most updates are like this now, but that doesn‚Äôt make them less important. | Photo by Amelia Holowaty Krales / The Verge
Well, here we are again: I‚Äôm writing an article to tell you that you should really update your iPhone, iPad, or Mac as soon as possible, because the latest software for them fixes some pretty nasty bugs. The security notes for iOS / iPadOS 15.6.1 and macOS 12.5.1 describe fixes for bugs in the OS‚Äô kernel (basically the core that controls everything) and WebKit that could allow attackers to run malicious code on your device. The notes also warn that the bugs may have actively been exploited. This is, unfortunately, something like the third or fourth time I‚Äôm writing a post explicitly asking people to update their iPhones or Macs to patch some pretty serious security flaws. And the truth is, I could‚Äôve written this exact post even more... Continue reading‚Ä¶

Embracer Group‚Äôs purchase of Middle-earth Enterprises opens up a wealth of opportunities to put all kinds of new spins on the characters, stories, and places of J.R.R. Tolkien‚Äôs Middle-earth. I am a horse girl at heart, and so a video game company purchasing the various rights to the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit universe means my dreams of a horse game involving the Rohirrim are that much closer to fruition. But Embracer didn‚Äôt just buy the gaming rights to Middle-earth; it bought (almost) all the rights. What else can Embracer do with all those juicy IPs, and how much of Middle-earth does the Swedish holding group own? Does Embracer Group own The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit? Short answer: no. Long answer: Nooooooo. To be clear,... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: A new way to smash the ‚Äòforever‚Äô out of ‚Äòforever chemicals‚Äô
entry.summary:
Absorbent booms are used to contain aqueous film forming foams (AFFF) from spilling into the surface water in Bensalem Township, Pennsylvania, on February 7th, 2019. AFFF used in fighting fires can contain PFAS. | Photo by Bastiaan Slabbers / NurPhoto via Getty Images
‚ÄúForever chemicals‚Äù have a reputation for being indestructible, persistent, and just about everywhere ‚Äî including many places where they shouldn‚Äôt be, like our drinking water. But now, there‚Äôs excitement about a new way to essentially smash these molecules to bits so that they don‚Äôt cause environmental and health problems. It‚Äôs described in research published today in the journal Science. There are caveats to the process, but to many experts‚Äô delight, it‚Äôs surprisingly simple for such a tough substance. ‚ÄúIt truly goes against everything I‚Äôve known for the past 10 years. And that‚Äôs really cool because someone else can then take this information and exploit it and adapt it to technologies that we need,‚Äù says Shira Joudan, an environmental... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Some Rivian customers aren‚Äôt happy the company canceled its most affordable electric truck
entry.summary:
Basically a price hike. | Photo by Mitchell Clark / The Verge
Rivian canceled the entry-level version of the R1T, effectively raising the price of its base model electric truck by over $6,000, according to an online forum for customers and later confirmed by the company. The company said in an email to customers that it was canceling the base ‚ÄúExplore‚Äù model, which started at $67,500, in favor of the $73,000 ‚ÄúAdventure‚Äù trim. Customers can either upgrade to the more expensive trim level or cancel their orders, the company advised. Rivian has also ‚Äúdiscontinued‚Äù the less expensive trim for its R1S electric SUV, which is expected to start shipping to customers later this year. In an email to preorder holders, a copy of which was shared with The Verge by Rivian spokesperson Tanya Miller, the company... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: John Fetterman‚Äôs Senate campaign has officially joined TikTok
entry.summary:
Photo by Nate Smallwood / Getty Images
Democratic Senate hopeful John Fetterman‚Äôs campaign to troll Republican opponent Dr. Mehmet Oz into defeat has dominated Facebook and Twitter over the last few weeks. But on Thursday, the campaign announced it is launching an official TikTok account to expand the reach of its already viral videos. The campaign formally launched the TikTok account with a video of Fetterman wearing his signature black hoodie and speaking directly to the camera. In the short video, Fetterman makes an expected jab at Oz and the festering controversy over the authenticity of the Trump-endorsed candidate‚Äôs Pennsylvania roots. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on TikTok now. Woo hoo!‚Äù Fetterman says at the end of the video. The campaign‚Äôs decision to join TikTok comes on the heels of a... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Def Con banned a social engineering star ‚Äî now he‚Äôs suing
entry.summary:
Illustration by Alex Castro / The Verge
In February, when the Def Con hacker conference released its annual transparency report, the public learned that one of the most prominent figures in the field of social engineering had been permanently banned from attending. For years, Chris Hadnagy had enjoyed a high-profile role as the leader of the conference‚Äôs social engineering village. But Def Con‚Äôs transparency report stated that there had been multiple reports of him violating the conference‚Äôs code of conduct. In response, Def Con banned Hadnagy from the conference for life; in 2022, the social engineering village would be run by an entirely new team. Now, Hadnagy has filed a lawsuit against the conference alleging defamation and infringement of contractual relations. The l... Continue reading‚Ä¶

entry.title: Open source runs on non-code contributions
entry.summary:
Open source runs on non-code contributions John E. Picozzi Thu, 08/18/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this At this year's DrupalCon North America, EPAM Solution Architect John Picozzi presented a talk about the importance of non-code contribution. He talked about how everyone can get involved and why he believes this is an important topic. This article is a text adaptation of John's talk; find a link below to a video recording of the complete presentation at DrupalCon. What is non-code contribution? I asked Google this question and got the following answer: "Any contribution that helps an open source project that does not involve writing code." Thanks, Google, but I already figured that out. If you asked me to dig deeper, I'd say it's about providing your time, skills‚Ä¶

entry.title: Tability for Clickup ‚Äî Bring your OKRs and goals to Clickup
entry.summary:
What's Tability?
I'm glad you ask! Our job is simple: to help teams stay focused on their goals. We built Tability because there were many great project management platform (like Clickup) but not a lot of options for goal-tracking. So we decided to tackle that issue to create a platform that is: - Intuitive and pleasant to use - Outcome-centric - Built for focus
Now, we just had to find a way to link our goals back to your work. And this is what this integration is doing!
Your OKRs ü§ù your tasks
With our new Clickup integration you get the benefits of having the best of everything: ‚úì an easy way to manage your OKRs in Tability. ‚úì a great way to view progress on projects in Clickup. ‚úì a simple way to link outcomes to outputs.
Sign up for Tability here ‚Üí https://www.tability.io ‚Äù

entry.title: snoopForms ‚Äî The open-source Typeform alternative, and much more
entry.summary:
half the deal.
Handling submission data gets really messy really fast. Add a large number of different forms and big, multi-disciplinary teams to the mix and you get... chaos üëº
Matti made this experience a few times building form and data management solutions for clients. He kept looking, and looking, and looking for a versatile, self-hostable solution built with a modern stack - until he decided to build one himself.
Because it's no fun alone, he hit me up with the idea for an open-source Typeform (but actually it's much more ü§ì).
We put our heads together and started building. Today, we are more than happy to share with a bigger audience what we have built so far üéâ
üíæ Data First snoopForms puts data at it's center. Forms are only the starting point of an interaction and a comprehe‚Ä¶

entry.title: Measure latency for embedded systems with this open source tool
entry.summary:
Measure latency for embedded systems with this open source tool Nicolas Rabault Wed, 08/17/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this When it comes to time synchronization for embedded systems in a distributed architecture, there are "soft" use cases (typical, everyday devices) and complex, or "hard," use cases (car brake systems, aerospace). It's easy to see that a hard use case has unique requirements and a low tolerance for latency. To put it another way, hard use cases have hard, real-time constraints. Latency is the bitter enemy of real-time computation. Latency, in the context of a critical real-time application, is the time between data generation and data reception. The reality is that when there is an interconnected network of several systems, there's latency. [ Re‚Ä¶

entry.title: 4 common issues with implementing Agile and how to address them
entry.summary:
4 common issues with implementing Agile and how to address them Kelsea Zhang Wed, 08/17/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this While working on the open source ZenTao project, I get constant feedback that getting Agile up and running is a big task in many organizations. As with any new process, you will run into issues, and many of them will feel unique to your organization. While context is important, there's a certain amount of abstraction possible after you've coached enough teams. This article covers the four most common issues I've encountered. While your Agile coach should analyze any actual problems in the context of your organization, knowing these general issues can help better prepare you and your teams for the transitional process. Note that I only discuss is‚Ä¶

entry.title: My practical advice for new programmers
entry.summary:
My practical advice for new programmers Sachin Samal Tue, 08/16/2022 - 03:00
3 readers like this 3 readers like this Have you ever been stuck or gone blank trying to solve a problem related to something that you just learned from YouTube or Google tutorials? You seem to understand every line of the code, but without the tutorial, you find yourself in a difficult position. If you have looked at problem-solving in HackerRank or LeetCode, you can relate to how an aspiring programmer feels seeing those challenges for the first time. Everything seems out of the box! Being unable to apply what you learned from a tutorial might make you doubt your knowledge and abilities as you begin to understand the basics of the programming language you're learning. Putting programming tutorials into pra‚Ä¶

entry.title: A look inside an EPUB file
entry.summary:
A look inside an EPUB file Jim Hall Tue, 08/16/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this eBooks provide a great way to read books, magazines, and other content on the go. Readers can enjoy eBooks to pass the time during long flights and train rides. The most popular eBook file format is the EPUB file, short for "electronic publication." EPUB files are supported across a variety of eReaders and are effectively the standard for eBook publication today. The EPUB file format is an open standard based on XHTML for content and XML for metadata, contained in a zip file archive. And because everything is based on open standards, we can use common tools to create or examine EPUB files. Let's explore an EPUB file to learn more about it. A guide to tips and tricks for C programming, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Try AsciiDoc instead of Markdown
entry.summary:
Try AsciiDoc instead of Markdown Seth Kenlon Mon, 08/15/2022 - 03:00
4 readers like this 4 readers like this I'm a happy user of the XML-based Docbook markup language. To me, it's a precise, explicit, and detailed system that allows me to have contextual and domain-specific metadata in what I write. Best of all, though, it can be transformed (that's what XML users call it when XML is converted into another format) into nearly any format, including HTML, EPUB, FO for PDF, plain text, and more. With great power comes a lot of typing, though, and sometimes Docbook feels like it's surplus to requirements. Luckily, there's AsciiDoc, a system of writing plain text with the same markup-less feel of Markdown, but that transforms to Docbook to take advantage of its precision and flexibility. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How ODT files are structured
entry.summary:
How ODT files are structured Jim Hall Mon, 08/15/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this Word processing files used to be closed, proprietary formats. In some older word processors, the document file was essentially a memory dump from the word processor. While this made for faster loading of the document into the word processor, it also made the document file format an opaque mess. Around 2005, the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS) group defined an open format for office documents of all types, the Open Document Format for Office Applications (ODF). You may also see ODF referred to as simply "OpenDocument Format" because it is an open standard based on the OpenOffice.org's XML file specification. ODF includes several file types,‚Ä¶

entry.title: Level up your HTML document with CSS
entry.summary:
Level up your HTML document with CSS Jim Hall Sat, 08/13/2022 - 03:00
2 readers like this 2 readers like this When you write documentation, whether that's for an open source project or a technical writing project, you should have two goals: The document should be written well, and the document should be easy to read. The first is addressed by clear writing skills and technical editing. The second can be addressed with a few simple changes to an HTML document. HyperText Markup Language, or HTML, is the backbone of the internet. Since the dawn of the "World Wide Web" in 1994, every web browser uses HTML to display documents and websites. And for almost as long, HTML has supported the stylesheet, a special addition to an HTML document that defines how the text should appear on the scree‚Ä¶
